Okay, on first glance, this games looks like a kids game. Don't get me wrong, the graphics are pretty colorful and childish, but it makes it up with gameplay. This games has one of the best MMO mechanics in the industry; you, the player, get to own ships, shoppes, and even islands (if you're rich enough). The direction of the economy is at the finger tips of merchants or pirates -- you choose.  The infusion of puzzles with the jobs on the sea makes for a great time if you join a random crew or sail with your friends. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves a pirates life (and puzzles).  Another great thing about the games is that it's cross-platform with Android and iOS.

Puzzle Pirates has been a longrunning game which has almost been around for a decade from what I recall, either way.  Puzzle Pirates is a game orienting on the exploration of a virtual sea world in which you will plunder, hunt (and potentially bet thousands if you're a poker player). Last time I had played this game was in 2009 and it is still familiar to me with barely any extreme changes that would put me off, the game itself is nowhere near Pay-2-Play and is entirely F2P as the economy relies on people who pay into the game. Gameplay itself is quite simple and revolves around minigames to either gain money, prowess or for fun.  Either way I recommend this to anyone who is wanting to play a simple F2P game and you have time aside to get accustomed to the game.

Even back when the game was young, it was already breaking the norms and creating something entirely different among games of its time. It continues to do so, now more than ever, being a sandbox MMO that offers something no one else can.  Skindeep, the game floats on dozens of different puzzles representing combat, keeping your ship seaworthy, crafting, harvesting, and just having a good time in the inns. The game is still much more deeper than that; the game is built on the shoulders of its players with a constant world heavily impacted by the politics of massive crews and flags and the entrepreneurship of individuals.  The path you choose is entirely up to you. As many will find, you will probably start off getting jobs aboard ships but this can quickly branch off into what YOU would like to do. You can continue to keep jobbing for crews or join your own doing the same thing, work at shoppes, run your own pillages as an officer in a crew, become a trader sailing island to island, become an adventurer or monster-hunter sailing to unknown dangers and looting giants, join the polticial scene among many of the top flags and crews who run a good fraction of the ocean, or even conquering entire islands owned by other players.  It's presented with a 2D setting and environment, but its very stylized and clean. The only true downside is the lack of effort put in by the developer's interest; the game has constantly taken blows due to poor management and bad decisions. You'd think a game like this would absolutley THRIVE in the current situation we are in now where puzzle and casual games rule. Alas, even Three Rings botched that up making a failure of a transition to mobile.  Still, what the game truly needs is more player activity. It's a highly social, very detailed yet entirely simple game that may be the best MMO made as of yet. If you're looking for something new and fresh, that is skill-based, detailed but without a steep learning curve, easy to learn but hard to master, or simply just one of the best casual games there is, then I highly recommend this to you.

Most complex economy in a free-to-play game. Ever.  Honestly, I can't believe this is a kid's game. You may own islands and be a governor, you can own shops and stalls, can own ships and crews - it's very sandboxy for its time.  Every time you want to craft items and sell it in your shop, you HAVE to play a mini-game. You can hire other players to 'work' for you. Every amount of orders they fill, you pay them. The puzzles are challenging but simple as well.  Prices for commodities go up and down just like in real life. You need these commodities to fulfil orders in your shop.  Long story short: this is the perfect game for any person who wants to become someone in real life but they can't. It's like a real-life simulator in a way.  9/10 - if they updated the graphics and made the game more action-oriented it'd get a straight up 10 from me. A masterpiece.

Before the days of standard F2P there was this little game. It was java based. I played this game in 2005 til about 06. It was one of those I used to take away from WoW(Back then things were much different). I'd puzzle and hang out with people. Got a girlfriend to play it, broke up with her. Faced her crew in a blockade and sunk her ship.   All to say this, the game WAS fun. However, it should have sank a long time ago. The subscriber oceans(Business model much like the current Sub games) is dead. There were 2 and they were well populated, now they are 1 and the last tally I did had 70 players on it... that's 1.2 islands to each player.  The dubloon oceans(The F2P counterparts) are still active but pulling in 1/5th the numbers they used too. And most of those are people searching for people who used to play the game and finding no one.   This Jolly Roger should be retired. It's sailed more than it's fair share of lasts.
